title: Government welcomes Hospital Authority's action plan for improving hospital services
content_text:
p>
	The Government today (October 22) welcomed the release of an action plan by 
	the Hospital Authority (HA), which has formulated concrete steps and a 
	timetable to implement the recommendations earlier proposed by the Steering 
	Committee on Review of the HA (Steering Committee) to improve the services 
	provided by the HA. A spokesman for the Food and Health Bureau said, "We note that the HA has 
	taken immediate actions to implement or will implement the recommendations 
	gradually within three years. The HA will regularly submit progress reports

gradually within three years. The HA will regularly submit progress reports 
	to the Government on the implementation of the action plan. The Government 
	will closely monitor the HA's work to ensure the timely and full 
	implementation of the recommendations. "With the full implementation of the various recommendations of the Steering 
	Committee, we are confident that the HA will continue to perform well its 
	role under our twin-track healthcare system as the cornerstone of our public 
	healthcare system, and to provide a safety net for all, amid the challenges

healthcare system, and to provide a safety net for all, amid the challenges 
	of an ageing population, increased prevalence of chronic diseases and rapid 
	advances in medical technology." Chaired by the Secretary for Food and Health, Dr Ko Wing-man, the Steering 
	Committee was established in 2013 to conduct a comprehensive review of the 
	operation of the HA. Members include healthcare professionals, academics, 
	representatives from the welfare sector and patients' rights associations. The Steering Committee has explored viable options for enhancing the cost

effectiveness and service quality of the HA with a view to providing it with 
	increased capacity to cope with future challenges. In its report released in 
	July 2015, the Steering Committee made a total of 10 major recommendations, 
	focusing on issues which are of concern to patients, community members and 
	HA staff. These issues include long waiting times, co-ordination problems of 
	clusters, resources allocation, and staffing and training arrangements.
